title: 107_s550
content: The Act titled "Indian and Alaska Native Foster Care and Adoption Services Amendments of 2001" allows Indian tribes to receive federal funds for foster care and adoption assistance. Children placed in tribal custody are now eligible for foster care funding under the Social Security Act. This includes Indian tribes or intertribal consortiums that do not operate a program under specific sections, but have a cooperative agreement with a State or submit arrangements to the Secretary. Children in tribal custody can receive foster care funding under the Social Security Act if they have a cooperative agreement with a State or submit arrangements to the Secretary for the provision of child welfare services. Children in tribal custody can receive foster care funding under the Social Security Act through cooperative agreements with a State or arrangements submitted to the Secretary for child welfare services. Programs operated by Indian tribal organizations are covered under SEC. 479B. Indian tribes can elect to operate a program under this part, following the same rules as a State. For plan approval, tribes must identify service areas and populations to be served, and ensure foster homes are approved. Indian tribes can operate a program under this part, following State rules. They must identify service areas, populations to be served, and approve foster homes to ensure child safety and accountability. The Federal medical assistance percentage for tribes is determined based on per capita income. The Federal medical assistance percentage for Indian tribes is based on per capita income, calculated using the service population defined in the tribe's plan. The per capita income of an Indian tribe is calculated based on the service population defined in the tribe's plan. The tribe can submit relevant information for consideration before the Secretary calculates the income. Administrative expenditures proportions are determined by the Secretary through regulations. The Secretary considers information before calculating per capita income for Indian tribes. Regulations determine administrative expenditure proportions, ensuring tribes receive no less than states. Indian tribes can use Federal or State funds to match eligible payments. The Secretary may modify requirements under this part for Indian tribes if it benefits the safety of children. Indian tribes can use Federal or State funds to match eligible payments under section 474. The Secretary may modify requirements under this part for Indian tribes if it benefits the safety of children. Indian tribes can enter into cooperative agreements with States for fund administration or payment. Intertribal consortiums can submit a single plan that meets the requirements of this section. An Indian tribe or intertribal consortium can enter into a cooperative agreement with a State for fund administration under section 471. Any existing cooperative agreements incorporating these provisions remain valid and enforceable, with the option to revoke or modify them as per the agreement terms. The cooperative agreement with a State for fund administration remains valid and enforceable, allowing either party to revoke or modify it. The Secretary must promulgate regulations within a year in consultation with Indian tribes and tribal organizations to implement this section. The amendments made by this section regarding the definitions of Indian tribe and tribal organization take effect on the date of enactment of this Act without the need for implementing regulations.
